did.abstract: Harold Karan Jacobson, professor of political science at the University of Michigan, was primarily involved in the areas of international relations, peace and security, behavior of states, foreign policy, and global environmental change. These papers represent his work as a professor, researcher, and author.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers (donor 9199) were received in May 2002

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Harold K. Jacobson papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Harold Karan Jacobson was born in Detroit, Michigan on June 28, 1929. In 1950 he received an A.B. degree "with distinction" from the University of Michigan. He received an M.A. and a Ph.D. from Yale University in 1952 and 1955, respectively. After research and teaching positions at Yale and the University of Houston, Jacobson joined the University of Michigan as an assistant professor of political science. He was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Sciences. He also served as the director of the Center for Political Studies at the University of Michigan Institute for Social Research (ISR), and was acting director of ISR from 1992-1995. He served as interim associate vice president for international affairs at Michigan from 1990 to 1992, president of the International Studies Association, and vice president of the International Political Science Association.

Jacobson was an expert on international institutions and politics, including international relations, law and organizations; foreign policy behavior of states; peace and security; and global environmental change. His research focused on the implementation of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and on democratic accountability and the use of force by international institutions. He played a leading role in the creation of the International Human Dimensions of Global Change Program, and was a member of the National Academy of Sciences National Research Council's Committee on the Human Dimensions of Global Change. Jacobson was the lead author of the 1994-1996 second scientific assessment of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

Jacobson authored, edited, or co-edited 12 books and numerous articles and monographs on international institutions and politics. His last book Engaging Countries: Strengthening Compliance with International Environmental Accords, was co-edited with Edith Brown Weiss of the Georgetown University Law Center, and is based upon National Implementation research.

Jacobson received numerous awards during his career, including an award for International Scientific Cooperation from the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1995. He also received the University of Michigan Press Award, the University of Michigan Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award, the Amoco Good Teaching Award, and the Excellence in Education Award. Harold Jacobson died at age 72, on August 13, 2001.

scopecontent.p: The Harold K. Jacobson papers are divided into seven series: Topical Files, National Implementation Project, Lectures, Papers Presented, Human Dimensions of Global and Environmental Change, University Materials, and Published Materials. Types of information and materials include research notes, correspondence, and lecture notes primarily related to Jacobson's work as a professor of political science and his interest and research into nations' adherence to international environmental laws and international politics.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Political Science.
controlaccess.subject: Environmental protection--International cooperation.
Environmental law, International.
Political science--Study and teaching.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series (0.8 linear feet, 1965-1996) consists of papers related to some of the committees, organizations, and projects that Jacobson was associated with. The files within this series are arranged alphabetically, and relate to fraternities, international initiative projects, conferences on international issues, international environmental policy, and committees within the University of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Conference on Teaching Ethics and Values in the University 1986
Indiana University Conference on Local and Global Common Problems October 1993
Ford Symposium on Becoming more International and Global 1992
Ford Foundation Request and Organization of Symposium 1991-1992
National Identity, Human Rights, and World Order Symposium 1992
University of Michigan Multi Lateral Trade Negotiations Project 1987

scopecontent.p: The National Implementation Project series (1.5 linear feet, 1991-1996) consists of materials related to Jacobson's work on this research project with Edith Brown Weiss of Georgetown to study nations' adherence to international environmental treaties. It contains such files as correspondence with country participants, grant applications and budgets for the project, background research into different nations' adherence to international environmental treaties, and working materials for the book that Jacobson co-edited with Weiss, titled Engaging Countries: Strengthening Compliance with International Environmental Accords.

did.unittitle: SSRC Proposal "International Laws and Global Environmental Change," 1991-1993
Bellagio Conference Proposal "Improving Compliance with International Environmental Accords," 1993
Narrative Report to the MacArthur Foundation 1993
Narrative Report to the Ford Foundation 1993
National Implementation Seminar in Geneva June 1993
Environmental Treaty Compliance Dataset, Codebook, and Worksheets
Convention on International Trade in endangered species (CITES)
UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
Book, "Engaging Countries: Strengthening Compliance with International Environmental Accords"
Charts Mailed to Authors of Political Unit Studies

scopecontent.p: The Lectures series (0.2 linear feet, 1963-1996) is arranged chronologically and contains notes and outlines from the various public lectures that Jacobson gave around the country and overseas. Each lecture is in its own file, and covers topics such as international relations, decision making in international organizations, and international policy. Classroom lectures are located within the University Materials series.

Scientific Club, "The UN: How Dangerous a Place?" 1979
"Conflicts and Alignments in Contemporary World Politics," 197?

UN Fifty, Ann Arbor, Michigan October 1994
Conference on Infusing International Dimensions into Political and Social Science Curricula, 199?

scopecontent.p: The Papers Presented series (0.2 linear feet, 1961-1987) is arranged chronologically and consists of different papers that Jacobson presented around the world on topics related to international relations, policy, and politics. This series also contains Jacobson's congressional hearing statement on U.S. policies in the United Nations.

did.unittitle: "IGOs and World Economic Policy in the perspective of Dependency Relationship," 1974
Department of State: Proposal Evaluation of the UN System's Development Assistance Activities 1979
"The UN System in the 1980s Crisis and Opportunity," 1987
"Soviet Policies Toward Economic and Social Aspects of the UN"
Human Dimensions of Global Environmental Change

scopecontent.p: The Human Dimensions of Global Environmental Change series (0.1 linear feet, 1988-1992) consists of materials relating to Jacobson's work in this research on human behavior as a factor in environmental change. It is subdivided into files such as research, publications, and hearings.

did.unittitle: National Geographic Research and Exploration Magazine, 1992
Hearing on Priorities in Global Climate Change Research for the Committee on Science, Space and Technology," Washington, D.C. 1991

scopecontent.p: The University Materials series (0.3 linear feet, 1957-1997) contains materials related to Jacobson's position as a professor at the University of Michigan. The files are made up of lecture notes, correspondence, awards, newsletter clippings, and documents related to Jacobson's tenure at the university.

did.unittitle: Faculty Personnel Records 1950-1985 (includes negatives of Jacobson)

scopecontent.p: The Publications series (0.1 linear feet, 1957-2001) consists of two folders of publications by Harold Jacobson. The publications are arranged chronologically.
